tossups.question: It's not Easter Island, but the falcon warrior was an important symbol of the birdman worship of a civilization centered around this geographic feature. The ball-and-stick game chunkey was invented near this geographic feature. A civilization centered on this geographic feature built the massive "Monk's Mound" at their town of (*) Cahokia ("kuh-HOH-kee-uh"). "The Big Fool says to move on" in a Pete Seeger song which contains a nickname for this geographic feature in its title. Jacques Marquette and Louis Jolliet were the first Europeans to explore the upper part of this river, which is nicknamed the "Big Muddy" and catastrophically flooded in 1927. For 10 points, name this river, the major trading route of the South Central US.
tossups.answer: Mississippi River [accept Mississippi River Valley or Mississippi Delta; prompt on Big Muddy before mentioned]

tossups.question: Alfred, Lord Tennyson was buried with his daughter Audrey’s copy of this play in his hands and read the line “'Hang there like a fruit, my soul, Till the tree die” just before he died. In Mrs. Dalloway, Clarissa repeatedly quotes the line “fear no more the heat o' the sun” from this play. George Bernard Shaw refinished this play to change the final act, removing scenes in which Jupiter visits a man in jail and where Polydore and (*) Cadwal wins a battle against the Romans. Produced in the 1610s, this play used Holinshed's Chronicles as a primary source. In this play, Iachimo steals a bracelet to prove to Posthumus Leonatus that Imogen has been unfaithful to him. For 10 points, name this Shakespeare play about an ancient “king of Britain''.

In Mrs. Dalloway, Clarissa repeatedly quotes the line “fear no more the heat o' the sun” from this play. George Bernard Shaw refinished this play to change the final act, removing scenes in which Jupiter visits a man in jail and where Polydore and (*) Cadwal wins a battle against the Romans.  Produced in the 1610s, this play used Holinshed's Chronicles as a primary source. In this play, Iachimo steals a bracelet to prove to Posthumus Leonatus that Imogen has been unfaithful to him. For 10 points, name this Shakespeare play about an ancient “king of Britain''.

tossups.question: In one story, Loki transforms a woman into a nut so that one of these creatures can carry her. Either a flame or one of these creatures was the form used to abduct Aegina. To enlist help with robbing the Garden of the Hesperides, Heracles had to kill one of these creatures with a poison arrow. The giant Thiassi ("thee-AH-see") adopted the form of one of these animals in order to kidnap Idunn. (*) Jaguars and these animals named the main special infantry forces of the Aztec army. In the USA, only Native Americans may legally obtain the feathers of these birds. One of these birds eats the regrowing liver of Prometheus. This bird is the subject of the Roman aquila symbol. For 10 points, name this bird that appears on the flags of many countries.

Paul Cohen used forcing to show that both the continuum hypothesis and several of these things were independent of their framework. Giovanni Sacherri borrowed from Omar Khayyam in laying the groundwork for (*) hyperbolic geometry while trying to prove one of these statements from four others in his book Euclid Freed of Every Flaw. One of these statements is that parallel lines never intersect, which cannot be proved. For 10 points, name these statements in math which must be assumed to be true.

tossups.question: Note to moderators: please read the answerline in its entirety before ruling on an answer.This condition occasionally appears in the abdominal wall along scars from bikini-line incisions or from past treatments. The observation of powder-burn lesions in the cul-de-sac can confirm this condition after initial observation of characteristic chocolate cysts on ultrasound. This most common cause of dysmenorrhea (“dis-men-oh-REE-uh”) can present similarly to PID when assessed with the visual analogue scale. This condition is typically self-medicated with NSAIDs ("N-said-s") or a (*) Nuvaring because it can take a decade to receive a formal diagnosis. Hysterectomy (“his-ter-ECK-toe-mee”) is not always sufficient to treat this condition, which almost always causes infertility. For 10 points, around 10% of women have what painful condition because of the spread of menstrual tissue outside their uterus?
tossups.answer: endometriosis [or endo; accept endometrioma, or abdominal wall endometriosis; prompt on heavy menstrual bleeding or synonyms like heavy flow, AWE, or ovarian cysts; prompt on answers which indicate severe or chronic period pain, menstrual cramps, pain during intercourse, non-menstrual pelvic pain, ovulation pain, deep dyspareunia, or CPP before "painful"; prompt on dysmenorrhea or infertility before mentioned]

tossups.question: The Tehuantepecer (“teh-WAN-teh-peh-sehr”) is an example of these phenomena associated with a blocking anticyclonic system. The creation of AABW (“A-A-B-W”) is driven by polynya (“poly-KNEE-a”) formation by these phenomena. Ice cover produces a density-driven variety of these phenomena that heats adiabatically as it descends mountains. Scatterometers measure the intensity and direction of these phenomena, which weaken near the Equator as part of (*) El Niño (“KNEE-nyoh”). Captain FitzRoy of the Beagle was the first to report the intensity of these phenomena with a subjective scale whose modern definition starts with “sea like a mirror”. The Beaufort (“BOW-fort”) scale is used to measure the strength of, for 10 points, what phenomenon, the movement of air from high pressure to low?
tossups.answer: winds [accept mountain-pass winds, katabatic winds, or trade winds; do not accept or prompt on “storms” or “currents”]

tossups.question: A line from this poem inspired the title of a novel in which Schar’s World gives refuge to a Culture Mind. A parody of this poem describes “a pair” that is “Bad as Albert and Lil”. The line “I hope you’ll make sense of the notes” concludes a series of five comedy limericks that Wendy Cope wrote, inspired by this poem. The speaker of this poem says “you know only / A heap of broken images” in a section that earlier described a (*) sled trip. Iain M. Banks's novel Consider Phlebas was titled in reference to this poem. The line “HURRY UP PLEASE ITS TIME” is repeated in a part of this poem titled “A Game of Chess”. Tiresias and Madame Sosostris are characters in this poem. This poem concludes with the line “Shantih shantih shantih”. For 10 points, name this long poem by T.S. Eliot.

Banks's novel Consider Phlebas was titled in reference to this poem. The line “HURRY UP PLEASE ITS TIME” is repeated in a part of this poem titled “A Game of Chess”. tossups.question: One of these places is frequently visited by the Queen in a novel by Alan Bennett, which is titled in reference to an essay collection by Virginia Woolf. Miss Saeki is in charge of a fictional one of these places named for the Komura family. The effete Oshima works in one of these places in the novel Kafka on the Shore. A fictional one of these places is comprised of randomly generated collections of (*) 410 parts. A monastery hosts one of these places which holds the finis africa in a novel featuring William and Adso. The blind Jorge of Burgos is in charge of one of these locations in the novel The Name of the Rose. For 10 points, what sort of book repository is “of Babel” in a story by Jorge Luis Borges?

parts_sanitized: Name this conflict. Mary Wollstonecraft wrote A Vindication of the Rights of Man in response to Edmund Burke’s Reflections on this European conflict.
Charles Dickens used this Scottish historian’s work on The French Revolution to write A Tale of Two Cities. This advocate of Great Man history coined the name “dismal science” for economics.
In To the Finland Station, Edmund Wilson extensively analysed the work on the Revolution by this Frenchman. This man coined the word Renaissance in its modern sense.
